title: Being a workplace martyr isn't healthy — here are 9 signs you may be one
text:
Sometimes, work will take over your life for a little. It's happened to almost everyone. But if it's always taking over your life, you may be a workplace martyr.

Workplace martyrs feel ashamed when they prioritize anything over work, or take time off.

And it's not a good thing to be one; you'll be on the road to burn out, and can strain relationships and friendships.

If you're never fully unplugged, or never attend any events with your teammates, you may be a martyr.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

We get it — life can be crazy at times, and work can feel overbearing. We've all been there: You're stuck at the office until late into the evening, answering calls on your vacation or skipping family events because you have an important project you need to get done, etc.

But then there are some people who stay late every day, never unplug on vacations, and have no sense of a work-life balance. Those people tend to be workplace martyrs. Being a workplace martyr means that you feel a sense of shame for taking time off or for prioritizing other obligations over your job. A workplace martyr is someone who puts their job first, always, and wants everyone to know it to prove just how painfully hardworking they are.

Being a work martyr isn't a good thing, however. It often leads to burnout, and it can put tension on other areas of your life — like your social life, including your friendships and relationships.

Here are nine signs that you're a workplace martyr — and that it's time to take a long hard look in the mirror to reevaluate how you do things.
description: If you feel ashamed whenever you take time off — or you just never do — then you may be your workplace's martyr.
